Waxy

I was having lunch at PJ's with one of my favorite clients last week and the conversation turned to the Bush government's recent round of tax cuts. "I'm opposed to those tax cuts," the retired college instructor declared, "because they benefit the rich. The rich get much more money back than ordinary taxpayers like you and I and that's not fair."
 
 "But the rich pay more in the first place," I argued, "so it stands to
 reason that they'd get more money back." I could tell that my friend was unimpressed by this meager argument. Even college instructors are a prisoner of the myth that the "rich" somehow get a free ride in USA. Nothing could be further from the truth.
 
 Let's put tax cuts in terms everyone can understand. Suppose that everyday 10 men go to PJ's for dinner, The bill for all ten comes to $100. If it was paid the way we pay our taxes, the first four men would pay nothing; the fifth would pay $1; the sixth would pay $3; the seventh $7; the eighth $12; the ninth $18. The tenth man (the richest) would pay $59.
 
 The 10 men ate dinner in the restaurant every day and seemed quite happy with the arrangement until the owner threw them a curve. Since you are all such good customers, he said, I'm going to reduce the cost of your daily meal by $20. Now dinner for the 10 only costs $80.
 
 The first four are unaffected. They still eat for free. Can you figure out how to divvy up the $20 savings among the remaining six so that everyone gets his fair share? The men realize that $20 divided by 6 is $3.33, but if they subtract that from everybody's share, then the fifth man and the sixth man would end up being paid to eat their meal. The restaurant owner suggested that it would be fair to reduce each man's bill by roughly the same amount and he proceeded to work out the amounts each should pay.
 
 And so the fifth man paid nothing, the sixth pitched in $2, the seventh paid $5, the eighth paid $9, the ninth paid $12, leaving the tenth man with a bill of $52 instead of $59. Outside the restaurant, the men began to compare their savings.
 
 "I only got a dollar out the $20," declared the sixth man pointing to the tenth, "and he got $7!" "Yeah, that's right," exclaimed the fifth man. I only saved a dollar, too. It's unfair that he got seven times more than me! "That's true," shouted the seventh man. "Why should he get $7 back when I got only $2? The wealthy get all the breaks." "Wait a minute," yelled the first four men in unison. "We didn't get anything at all. The system exploits the poor." 
 
 The nine men surrounded the tenth and beat him up. The next night he didn't show up for dinner, so the nine sat down and ate without him. But when it came time to pay the bill, they discovered something important. They were $52 short!
 
 And that, boys and girls, and college instructors, is how the US's tax system works. The people who pay the highest taxes get the most benefit from a tax reduction. Tax them too much, attack them for being wealthy, and they just may not show up at the table anymore. There are lots of good restaurants in Switzerland and the Caribbean.
 
 Waxy

The question is of course where the tax cut comes from... If it comes from cut backs in the public sector, it`s probably a net loss for those who don`t pay taxes at all, as well as those who pay the smaller share. If it comes from loans, you are taking it from future generations. If it comes from the military, it could be argued to be a net loss for those who pays nothing or little (as they loose "national security"). If its a tax cut based on increased revenues, no one is actually hurt (except in relative terms).

 That's one of the more interesting debates about current US tax cuts, as to who's actually picking up the tab. Those in favor are believers in tax cuts generating increased commercial activity, a correct assumption under past economic conditions, and those against pointing out that in the current economic environment it amounts to reduced tax revenue being subsidized by expanded debt. 
 
 In an economy that's primarily driven by consumer and government spending based on debt without true economic growth, those who pay no or few taxes receive direct benefits with refunds such as last year's dependent refund, but will eventually suffer when the debt incurred from reduced revenue forces cutbacks in social services used primarily by that income group. As a double whammy, those not participating in the direct refunds, those taxpayers who shoulder the bulk of our tax burden, will service the debt incurred due to the reduced revenue, which is a basically a form of redistribution of wealth. Spending money you don't have without assured replenishment is ugly no matter where you stand. Unless, of course, you're a politician being re-elected into that life of power and seemingly unlimited benefits and perks.

We're still talking basic finance; revenue less expenses equals a plus or minus. If a minus, it becomes national debt. If tax cuts do not generate enough additional revenue to replace the lost revenue (tax cuts), they're defined as an economic policy failure regardless of the political spin. Regan's worked because we had an industrial base that could still respond to stimulation. We're now a service level economy. Since 2000, we've actually had a decrease in personal and corporate tax revenue, the first time that has happened since the 1920s. Most economists now book the tax cuts directly as lost revenue for purposes of forecasting. Examine the composition of our budget and the loss of revenue from tax cuts stands out like a sore thumb as a contribution to the deficit.
 
 Maybe the general public believes tax cuts are stimulating our economy due to the massive media coverage afforded them as a political campaign plank, but that's just more hogwash to give them a warm fuzzy feeling before the piper eventually puts out both hands for payment.
 
 It doesn't matter who's in office, spending vast amounts of money that's just not there is irresponsible.

One thing we may disagree about...corporations don't pay taxes. They may appear to pay "corporate taxes" but these are simply passed on to the consumers.

 
 A provision for taxes is part of any corporate income statement. It's commonly referred to as a 'below the line' item, which is subtracted from net profit. Passing that on is just another cost of doing business and determines your profitability. That's since the beginning of organized society when farmers gave a certain amount of harvest to the king for providing the army that protected them. Like the farmer, larger corporations have to make sure they still have enough to pay stockholders, so think of it as the farmer having enough crop left to feed himself and his family after the King's share. You can complicate it a little to have a better relation to contemporary society; If the king demands too much, the farmhands demand too much and the King's tax collector insures his brother of a job by having the king implement farm safety devices his brother can inspect, there won't be enough left over for the farmer, so he gets a regular job and buys his food from King X's nation, where the farmer has lower costs and can sell part of his crops. 
 
 You can easily relate that to tax cuts by being the king and letting the farmer give less crop share each year by borrowing money from the hunger god, but the farmer will still owe the crop share plus interest to the hunger god. Eventually, the farmer can't grow enough to feed more than the king and compounded interest to the hunger god, but the king will still be fat. And all of a sudden the hunger god will want all the outstanding crop debt to loan to the Chinese, who grow more profitable crops and pay higher interest.

 No, he increased his company's operating expense, reducing his pre-tax net profits by the amount of the bill.
